text: Pterostichus madidus, commonly known as the black clock beetle, is a species of ground beetle native to Europe.Fauna EuropaeaCarl H. Lindroth 1974 Coleoptera. Carabidae. Handbooks for the Identification of British Insects Vol 4 Part 2. Royal Entomological Society,London pdf The black clock beetle typically grows between 14–20mm in length, and is black in colouration, with legs that are usually red, reddish brown, or black. It can be found most abundantly in summer, and breeds during the autumn. It is commonly found in gardens, grasslands, and dry woodland, under stones, in grass, or in loose bark. ==References== Category:Pterostichus Category:Beetles of Europe Category:Beetles described in 1775 Category:Taxa named by Johan Christian Fabricius
title: Pterostichus madidus
